feed.title: Data Is Plural
feed.subtitle: A weekly newsletter of useful/curious datasets.

entry.title: Data Is Plural â€” 2023.08.02 edition
entry.content:
Nursing home inspections, local ideology, COVID-19 in deer, Colombian public-sector algorithms, and forageable fruit.

Â 

ğŸ“¬ Reader Dea B used the Global Open Data Barometer, featured in DIP 2022.05.18, to create an exploratory data story on the state of open data around the world. (Have you published something with data you found via DIP? Click here to let me know.)

Â 

Nursing home inspections. A couple of weeks ago, ProPublica launched a major update to its Nursing Home Inspect database, originally published in 2012 (and briefly mentioned in DIP 2016.07.06). The new version â€œincludes more data, new views that summarize problems, and advanced search features.â€ As an accompanying guide explains, the database now â€œcovers nearly 400,000 deficiencies from over 90,000 reports at over 15,000 homes.â€ The project links to its source data, including the federal governmentâ€™s list of Medicare-certified nursing homes and the date, regulation, scope/severity, and narrative text of all deficiencies. Tip: The Seattle Times provides guidance for downloading those deficiency records. Later today: ProPublica is hosting a webinar about the updated database.

Â 

Local ideology. â€œLittle is known about the American publicâ€™s policy preferences at the level of Congressional districts, state legislative districts, and local municipalities,â€ Chris Tausanovitch and Christopher Warshaw wrote in the Journal of Politics a decade ago. To address the issue, the researchers applied Bayesian statistical methods to large public-opinion surveys to generate numeric â€œideal pointâ€ (left-vs-right) estimates at many geographic levels. Through their American Ideology Project, they have since updated these estimates, including most recently with data through 2021. Previously: Ideology estimates for state legislators (DIP 2020.01.01), updated in April 2023, and members of Congress (DIP 2023.03.01). [h/t Mike Stucka]

Â 

COVID-19 in deer. Aijing Feng et al. â€œcollected 8,830 respiratory samples from free-ranging white-tailed deer across Washington, D.C. and 26 states in the United States between November 2021 and April 2022.â€ The researchers sequenced the COVID-19 genomes from 391 of the samples that tested positive for the virus, finding that the infections â€œoriginated from at least 109 independent spillovers from humans, which resulted in 39 cases of subsequent local deer-to-deer transmission and three cases of potential spillover from white-tailed deer back to humans.â€ The studyâ€™s public spreadsheets include data about each sequenced sample (collection date, state, virus lineage, etc.), each spillover event, and more. [h/t Tyler Dedrick]

Â 

Colombian public-sector algorithms. Juan David GutiÃ©rrez et al. have compiled a spreadsheet listing 113 automated decision systems (â€œsistemas de decisiÃ³n automatizadaâ€) in the Colombian public sector. Each entry lists the systemâ€™s name, government entity, level of government (national, department, municipal), sector, description, objectives, data used, various categorizations, and much more. The project also includes a spreadsheet of the 300+ sources used in the compilation.

Â 

Forageable fruit. The Falling Fruit project â€œis a celebration of the overlooked culinary bounty of our city streets.â€ It provides a map â€” â€œnot the first of its kind, but [aspiring] to be the worldâ€™s most comprehensiveâ€ â€”Â and downloadable dataset of 1.5 million locations of edible plants in public, although not strictly fruit. The entries come from user contributions, as well as imports of community maps and tree inventories. [h/t Susie Cambria]

Â 

Dataset suggestions? Criticism? Praise? Send foraged feedback to jsvine@gmail.com, or just reply to this email. // Looking for past datasets? This spreadsheet contains them all. // Visit data-is-plural.com to subscribe and to browse past editions.
entry.summary: Nursing home inspections, local ideology, COVID-19 in deer, Colombian public-sector algorithms, and forageable fruit.

entry.title: Data Is Plural â€” 2023.07.26 edition
entry.content:
Natural resources revenue, gender and diplomacy, nearly 8 million PDFs, Iberian orcas, and Taskmaster tasks.

Â 

ğŸ“¬ â€œSome Milwaukee County parents leaving workforce due to sky-high child care costs,â€ reader Tyler Dedrick reported in Wisconsin Watch last month, referencing the National Database of Childcare Prices featured in DIP 2023.04.26. (Have you published something with data you found via DIP? Click here to let me know.)

Â 

Natural resources revenue. To extract minerals, coal, oil, or gas from US federal land, Native American land, or the Outer Continental Shelf, companies must pay various royalties, rents, and bonuses to the Office of Natural Resources Revenue, which then distributes those payments â€”Â amounting to billions of dollars per year â€” to the federal government, local governments, tribes, and individuals. Through its data portal, the agency provides annual and monthly breakdowns of revenue, disbursements, and production, which you can download, query, and visually explore. Related: The Bureau of Land Management also provides â€œdata that include the numbers of BLM-administered oil and gas leases, applications for permit to drill, and oil and gas wellsâ€ on federal land. As seen in: â€œHow much oil and gas comes from federal territory?â€ (USAFacts).

Â 

Gender and diplomacy. Birgitta Niklasson and Ann Townsâ€™s GenDip dataset â€œmaps the extent to which states appoint men, women and other diplomats to different kinds of bilateral ambassador postings.â€ The data cover 200+ countries and 10 specific years between 1968 and 2021. For each diplomat and year, the dataset indicates their sending country, receiving country, type of diplomatic title (e.g., ambassador, minister, etc.), and gender, which is â€œbased on titles (e.g. Mr/Mrs, prince/princess, baron/baroness, etc.), pronouns used when referring to the diplomat, or the recognition of names as either female or male.â€ The team has also produced a series of visualizations based on the data.

Â 

Millions of PDFs. As part of its SafeDocs project, DARPA has compiled a corpus of â€œnearly 8 million PDFs gathered from across the web in July/August of 2021.â€ To create it, the authors began with the URLs of PDF files identified by Common Crawl (DIP 2021.04.21), fetched their complete contents, and recorded metadata about each file and where it was found. â€œAt the time of its creation, this is the largest single corpus of real-world (extant) PDFs that is publicly available,â€ they write.

Â 

Iberian orcas. The website orcas.pt publishes monthly, downloadable maps indicating the date, time, and location of orca sightings and attacks off the coasts of Portugal and Spain. Run by Rui Alves as a personal project, the project gathers its data through a network of local sailors. Related: The Cruising Association, in collaboration with Grupo de Trabajo Orca AtlÃ¡ntica, publishes maps and detailed reports of orca interactions, including â€œuneventful passages.â€ [h/t Soph Warnes]

Â 

Comedians, challenged. At TaskMaster.Info, Karl Craven is â€œobsessively documenting the international Taskmaster franchise,â€ which began as a British game show on which comedians compete to win challenges such as watermelon speed-eating and high-fiving strangers. Reddit user Alohamori has used the site and other sources to create a â€œridiculously comprehensiveâ€ database of that information, enabling queries such as the fastest-completed tasks, tasks awarding zero points, and episodes ending in ties. Bonus link: Taskmasterâ€™s official YouTube channel.

Â 

Dataset suggestions? Criticism? Praise? Send obsessively documented feedback to jsvine@gmail.com, or just reply to this email. // Looking for past datasets? This spreadsheet contains them all. // Visit data-is-plural.com to subscribe and to browse past editions.
entry.summary: Natural resources revenue, gender and diplomacy, nearly 8 million PDFs, Iberian orcas, and Taskmaster tasks.

entry.title: Data Is Plural â€” 2023.07.12 edition
entry.content:
US military interventions, the latest White House visitors, NY prison employee misconduct, Australian mine production, and â€œthe global human day.â€

Â 

US military interventions. For the Military Intervention Project, Sidita Kushi and Monica Duffy Toft have constructed a dataset of â€œall instances of US military intervention from 1776 until 2019, alongside key drivers and consequences of these interventions.â€ The 392 cases include wars, occupations, major troop deployments, humanitarian assistance, and other military actions abroad. The dataset categorizes their objectives, use of force, and outcomes; indicates their location, foreign states involved, starting/ending year, and human costs; and provides many additional variables. Its sources include government publications, media reports, other datasets (such as the International Military Intervention and Military Intervention by Powerful States projects), and more. [h/t David Vine]

Â 

The latest White House visitors. In May 2021, the Biden-Harris administration began releasing its logs of visitors to the White House. The records now include 500,000+ entries from January 2021 to March 2023, featuring 350,000+ distinct names and indicating the visitâ€™s timing, visitee, meeting location, and more. Caveat: â€œHowever, a Bloomberg News analysis of the data found duplications, anomalies and missing names,â€ write Eric Fan and Josh Wingrove. â€œFor example, the records [â€¦] show just five visits from Nancy Pelosi when she was House Speaker, despite at least 20 known instances when she was there.â€ Previously: Official logs from the Obama-Biden White House, plus ProPublicaâ€™s and Politicoâ€™s attempts to compile them for Trump-Pence (DIP 2017.11.29).

Â 

NY prison employee misconduct. For a series of articles (co-published with the New York Times) investigating abuse by prison guards in New York State, The Marshall Project obtained and analyzed data representing 12 years of Department of Corrections and Community Supervision employee disciplinary notices. The newsroom is publishing those records, which theyâ€™ve converted from two PDFs into tabular data, along with additional context and caveats. The records contain ~6,000 (non-redacted) notices; they indicate the employee name, title, facility, union, type of misconduct, case disposition, description, and penalty, among other details.

Â 

Australian mine production. â€œNo [â€¦] study has ever compiled a national mine production data set which includes basic mining data such as ore processed, grades, extracted products (e.g., metals, concentrates, saleable ore) and waste rock,â€ writes Gavin M. Mudd, whose new dataset aims to do exactly that for Australia from 1799 to 2021. It contains mine-by-mine metrics, as well as annual production by state and element/mineral.

Â 

â€œThe global human day.â€ By harmonizing â€œdata collected by national statistics agencies, international organizations, and researchers from over 140 countries,â€ William Fajzel et al. have â€œassemble[d] a complete estimate of what humans are doing, averaged over time and across the entire population, to provide [what] we refer to as the global human day.â€ Their published data include global and national estimates for 24 subcategories, such as sleep (~9 hours) and childcare (~17 minutes).

Â 

Dataset suggestions? Criticism? Praise? Send globally-averaged feedback to jsvine@gmail.com, or just reply to this email. // Looking for past datasets? This spreadsheet contains them all. // Visit data-is-plural.com to subscribe and to browse past editions.
entry.summary: US military interventions, the latest White House visitors, NY prison employee misconduct, Australian mine production, and â€œthe global human day.â€

entry.title: Data Is Plural â€” 2023.06.28 edition
entry.content:
Unanalyzed sexual assault kits, global income deciles, US fire statistics, species introduced to the Antarctic, and Swedish air traffic control.

Â 

ğŸ“¬ Reader Mike Freeman has mapped 36 years of Canadian wildfires, using data featured in DIP 2023.06.14, and demonstrates how he did it. (Have you published something with data you found via DIP? Click here to let me know.)

Â 

Rape kit backlogs. The actual number of unanalyzed sexual assault kits in the United States is unknown. But last year â€œat least 25,000 untested rape kits sat in law enforcement agencies and crime labs across the country,â€ according to rape kit backlog data compiled by USAFacts, based on responses by 30 states and DC to public records requests. Elizabeth â€œBetsyâ€ Kim, who led the project, has published the raw records the agencies and labs provided, as well as her correspondence with them. The core data indicate the number of kits in each backlog each year between 2018 and 2022; the backlog definition (in number of days) the state used in the data they provided; and, of the kits received by crime labs in 2022, how many were tested within 30 days.

Â 

Global income deciles. Kanishka B. Narayan et al. â€œpresent a consistent dataset of income distributions across 190 countries from 1958 to 2015 measured in terms of net income.â€ Where net income statistics were unavailable, the authors imputed the deciles from consumption data or the countryâ€™s Gini coefficient. Their paper also provides a comparison of their dataset to the United Nations Universityâ€™s World Income Inequality Database (DIP 2016.06.01), the Luxembourg Income Study Database, and the World Bankâ€™s PovcalNet (now the Poverty and Inequality Platform). Also previously: The Global Repository of Income Dynamics (DIP 2022.11.09) and Frederick Soltâ€™s Standardized World Income Inequality Database (DIP 2019.12.04).

Â 

US fire statistics. The US National Interagency Fire Center â€œis home to the national fire management programs of each federal fire agency, along with partners,â€ such as the National Weather Service. It provides a range of aggregate statistics as HTML tables, including firefighting suppression costs by year, the number and size of human-caused wildfires by year and geography, similar counts for lightning-caused fires, and prescribed fires by year and agency. Reader Michael Nolan has converted the prescribed fire tables, which cover 1998 to 2019, into CSV files. Previously: Monitoring Trends in Burn Severity (DIP 2017.10.11).

Â 

Species introduced to the Antarctic. â€œFrom the earliest expeditions to Antarctica and the Southern Ocean Islands, humans have intentionally and accidentally introduced non-native species to the region,â€ write Rachel I. Leihy et al., who have assembled a dataset of â€œintroduced and invasive alien speciesâ€ documented in the region. The dataset identifies 3,000+ location-species combinations, providing their â€œestablishment, eradication status, dates of introduction, habitat, and evidence of impact,â€ plus reference citations.

Â 

Swedish air traffic control. Jens Nilsson and Jonas Ungerâ€™s Swedish Civil Air Traffic Control dataset contains 13 non-contiguous weeks of â€œflight plans, clearances from air traffic control, surveillance data and trajectory prediction data,â€ corresponding to 167,000+ scheduled commercial flights in 2017. The records come from two control centers, in MalmÃ¶ and Stockholm.

Â 

Dataset suggestions? Criticism? Praise? Send cleared-for-takeoff feedback to jsvine@gmail.com, or just reply to this email. // Looking for past datasets? This spreadsheet contains them all. // Visit data-is-plural.com to subscribe and to browse past editions. // Listen to the podcast to hear humans. // Swing by Instagram and Mastodon for screenshots.
entry.summary: Unanalyzed sexual assault kits, global income deciles, US fire statistics, species introduced to the Antarctic, and Swedish air traffic control.

entry.title: Data Is Plural â€” 2023.06.14 edition
entry.content:
Canadian wildfires, climate finance, Pennsylvania competency cases, ad-targeting labels, and food defect thresholds.

Â 

ğŸ“¬ Reader Caroline Beavon built an interactive, first-name-centric dataviz based on Morgane Laouenan et al.â€™s dataset of Wikipedia-notable people, featured in DIP 2022.07.20. (Have you published something with data you found via DIP? Click here to let me know.)

Â 

Canadian wildfires. The Canadian Wildland Fire Information System monitors wildfires and fire-conducive conditions across the country. It publishes daily maps of its Fire Weather Index, satellite-detected hotspots, and fire intensity predictions, among other analyses. Its Canadian National Fire Database provides the perimeters, dates, sizes, and other metadata for tens of thousands of fires, spanning decades. In the agencyâ€™s datamart, you can find additional downloads of tabular and geospatial data, including burned-area statistics, active fires, and current conditions. Related: The Canadian Interagency Forest Fire Centreâ€™s dashboard of active fires. Previously: The Global Wildfire Information System (DIP 2022.07.27). [h/t Michael Nolan]

Â 

Climate finance. â€œRich nations say theyâ€™re spending billions to fight climate changeâ€ in developing countries, notes a recent Reuters investigation, which found some of this climate finance going to â€œquestionableâ€ projects, â€œincluding a coal plant, a hotel and chocolate shops.â€ To help find those examples, Reuters teamed up with Big Local News to extract â€œ43,844 records [from the] [Fifth](https://unfccc.int/BR5), Fourth, and Third Biennial reports that developed countries submitted to the U.N. Climate Change secretariat.â€ Each of the records represents a reported contribution, listing the recipient country/region, program funded, funding amount, sector, status, and more. Read more: â€œHow you can use climate finance data we collected for local stories around the globeâ€ (Big Local News).

Â 

Pennsylvania competency cases. Earlier this year, Spotlight PA and the Pittsburgh Institute for Nonprofit Journalism published an investigation into Pennsylvaniaâ€™s competency system, which is â€œsupposed to protect people with mental health issues from prosecution if they cannot understand the legal system and cannot aid in their own defense.â€ The team has also published the data it received from the stateâ€™s court administrators, with information about 697 cases that involved competency proceedings between 2018 to mid-2022. The records, available for 23 counties, indicate each caseâ€™s court, filing date, charges, disposition, sentencing, attorneys, plus the type and timing of 1,400+ competency-related docket filings. [h/t Matt Dempsey]

Â 

Ad-targeting labels. The Markup has obtained, analyzed, and published a spreadsheet of 650,000+ ad-targetable â€œaudience segmentsâ€ (described by labels such as â€œDepression Propensity - Reach Tier 2â€) and their data suppliers. The spreadsheet â€”Â flagged to The Markup by privacy researcher Wolfie Christl â€”Â was, until recently, linked from the website of a Microsoft-owned ad platform. â€œThe Markup found thousands of rows in the file that indicate sensitive audience groupings,â€ including those related to medical issues, race/ethnicity, political activity, addiction, and more. [h/t Sharon Machlis]

Â 

Food defect thresholds. â€œHow many rat hairs in your macaroni before the FDA considers it adulterated?â€ asks Cody Winchester, who has found the answer in the Food and Drug Administrationâ€™s Food Defect Levels Handbook. That guideâ€™s â€œaction levelsâ€ table lists 180 criteria for 111 commodities, indicating the â€œmaximum levels of natural or unavoidable defects in foods for human use that present no health hazard.â€ Winchester has converted the table into a JSON file. The answer: An â€œaverage of 4.5 rodent hairs or more per 225 grams in 6 or more subsamples.â€

Â 

Dataset suggestions? Criticism? Praise? Send fewer than 4.5 rodent hairs per 225 grams of feedback to jsvine@gmail.com, or just reply to this email. // Looking for past datasets? This spreadsheet contains them all. // Visit data-is-plural.com to subscribe and to browse past editions. // Listen to the podcast to hear humans. // Swing by Instagram and Mastodon for screenshots.
entry.summary: Canadian wildfires, climate finance, Pennsylvania competency cases, ad-targeting labels, and food defect thresholds.

entry.title: Data Is Plural â€” 2023.06.07 edition
entry.content:
Pesticide use, commercial space launches, firearm suicide rates, Harvardâ€™s library holdings, and ransomware negotiations.

Â 

ğŸ“¬ Reader (and DIP podcast guest) Vikram Oberoi has analyzed the BuzzFeed News â€œTrendingâ€-strip dataset featured in DIP 2023.05.24, identifying the longest-featured articles â€” overall, by year, and by month. (Have you published something with data you found via DIP? Click here to let me know.)

Â 

Pesticide use. As part of its National Water-Quality Assessment Project, the US Geological Survey publishes maps and datasets that estimate local pesticide usage, based on â€œproprietary surveys of farm operations.â€ The datasets provide high/low estimates (measured in kilograms) by county, chemical, and year, as well as by crop group for each state. The most recent â€œpreliminaryâ€ figures refer to 2019, with the next release not scheduled until â€œlate 2024.â€ Read more: â€œMove to change how U.S. tracks pesticide use sparks protest,â€ an article by Virginia Gewin in Science, reporting on the pushback against USGSâ€™s decision â€œto reduce the number of chemicals it tracks and to release updates less frequently.â€ [h/t Walt Hickey]

Â 

Commercial space launches. The Federal Aviation Administration regulates the United Statesâ€™ commercial space transportation industry. The agency publishes HTML tables listing operator licenses, permits for experimental operations, licensed launches, and more. The 552 launches listed go back to 1989; each row indicates the date, payload, vehicle name, company, and siteâ€™s state (or â€œPacific Oceanâ€). Related: The FAAâ€™s map and descriptions of the countryâ€™s commercial spaceports. [h/t Chartr]

Â 

Firearm suicide rates. A recent paper (published in the American Journal of Preventive Medicine) and dataset by Megan Kang and Elizabeth Rasich â€œextends an existing proxy for household gun ownership rates â€” the rate of firearm suicide divided by suicide (FSS) â€” from 1949 to 2020, including new coverage for the 1949 to 1972 period.â€ For each state and year, the dataset provides the count and population-adjusted rate of suicides, firearm suicides, homicides, and firearm homicides, among other figures. The first 30 years of firearm suicide/homicide counts had to be transcribed from scanned National Center for Health Statistics reports; later figures come from the CDCâ€™s WONDER and WISQARS systems.

Â 

Harvardâ€™s library holdings. Harvard Library, â€œthe oldest library system in the United States and the worldâ€™s largest academic library,â€ provides several ways to access detailed metadata about its holdings, including its LibraryCloud API and bulk downloads. The millions of items described include not only books, but also â€œjournals, scores, databases, sound recordings, films and video, images, maps,â€ and more. Previously: Metadata from the Library of Congress (DIP 2017.05.24).

Â 

Ransomware negotiations. Negotiations between ransomware victims and their attackers â€œare usually not shared widely, limiting the understanding of the process,â€ writes journalist ValÃ©ry Marchive, whose repository of chat transcripts â€œaims at changing that, in a respectful manner for the victims of cyberattacks: chats are anonymized as long as the victim hasnâ€™t been publicly disclosed, either by the attackers or in the media.â€ [h/t Duncan Geere]

Â 

Dataset suggestions? Criticism? Praise? Send cryptovirological feedback to jsvine@gmail.com, or just reply to this email. // Looking for past datasets? This spreadsheet contains them all. // Visit data-is-plural.com to subscribe and to browse past editions. // Listen to the podcast to hear humans. // Swing by Instagram and Mastodon for screenshots.
entry.summary: Pesticide use, commercial space launches, firearm suicide rates, Harvardâ€™s library holdings, and ransomware negotiations.

entry.title: Data Is Plural â€” 2023.05.31 edition
entry.content:
Correctional control, local business, crowd accidents, Antarctic geology, and NYC sidewalk scaffolding.

Â 

ğŸ‘‹ Based on reader feedback, I'm exploring the idea of writing one or more in-depth guides to specific datasets. I'd be grateful if you filled out this short survey on the topic. Thanks!

Â 

Correctional control. The Prison Policy Initiativeâ€™s Punishment Beyond Prisons report cross-references data from the Bureau of Justice Statistics and several other sources to count or estimate the number of people under eight forms of â€œcorrectional controlâ€ in each state and DC: federal prisons, state prisons, local jails, Indian Country jails, youth confinement, involuntary commitment, parole, and probation â€” approximately 5.5 million people in total. Related: The Census of Juveniles in Residential Placement, one of the reportâ€™s sources, provides a tool to tabulate youth confinement counts by sex, age, race, status, offense, and facility characteristics. [h/t Mike Wessler]

Â 

Local business. Despite the name, the Census Bureauâ€™s County Business Patterns datasets cover a range of geographic units, including states, congressional districts, metro areas, counties, and ZIP codes. Generated from the Bureauâ€™s confidential Business Register, they provide the number of establishments and (noise-infused) employee counts and payroll figures, disaggregated by industry code. Last month, the Bureau released the data for 2021. Historical availability varies; the Bureau directly provides data for counties back to 1986, and for ZIP codes back to 1994, for example. Fabian Eckert and colleagues, meanwhile, have converted two older archives of the records into comparable data, spanning 1946 to 1974 and 1975 onward.

Â 

Crowd accidents. Claudio Feliciani et al. have compiled a dataset of 281 crowd accidents from 1900 to 2019, based on â€œa comprehensive investigation of the press and media reports.â€ The researchers focus on accidents with at least one fatality or ten injuries â€œcaused by a collective crowd motion which could have been potentially prevented by employing a different design or through a proper crowd management.â€ The dataset lists each accidentâ€™s date, country, coordinates, gathering type (sport, religious, political, etc.), fatality and injury counts, crowd size, and sources. The deadliest accident included, by far, is the 2015 Mina stampede. [h/t Neil Martin]

Â 

Antarctic geology. Antarcticaâ€™s surface is mostly ice, but thereâ€™s also lots of rock. In a recent paper, the Scientific Committee on Antarctic Researchâ€™s GeoMAP team describes building the â€œfirst detailed geological map dataset covering all of Antarctica,â€ assembled and refined from 589 sources. The dataset, which you can download or explore as an interactive map, uses 99,000+ polygons to describe the rock-scape, associating each unit with a name (or group name), rock type, lithology, geologic period, and more.

Â 

NYC sidewalk scaffolding. New York Cityâ€™s Department of Buildings publishes a map and dataset of active permits for â€œsidewalk sheds,â€ the ubiquitous, temporary structures (often colloquially called scaffolding) meant to shield pedestrians from falling debris. Each of the ~9,000 entries indicates the permit address, date issued, material, linear feet, age, and more. The oldest shed has had a permit for more than 17 years. Read more: An introduction to the sheds and several visualizations of the data, by BetaNYCâ€™s Zhi Keng He. [h/t Giuseppe Sollazzo]

Â 

Dataset suggestions? Criticism? Praise? Send debris-sheltered feedback to jsvine@gmail.com, or just reply to this email. // Looking for past datasets? This spreadsheet contains them all. // Visit data-is-plural.com to subscribe and to browse past editions. // Listen to the podcast to hear humans. // Swing by the Instagram and/or Mastodon account for multimedia and bonus links.
entry.summary: Correctional control, local business, crowd accidents, Antarctic geology, and NYC sidewalk scaffolding.

entry.title: Data Is Plural â€” 2023.05.24 edition
entry.content:
Aviation accident investigations, the top of BuzzFeed News, forty years of financial reforms, parking reforms, and protected European ham.

Â 

Aviation accident investigations. Through its Case Analysis and Reporting Online service, the National Transportation Safety Board provides information about all US civil aviation accident investigations since 1983; another NTSB tool includes earlier cases, going back to 1963. The agency also provides bulk data downloads, covering the full span. Those files link each investigated event to details regarding the aircraft involved, engines, crew, injuries/fatalities, narratives, findings, and more. Related: In February, the agency launched an interactive dashboard summarizing accidents from 2012 to 2021. [h/t Gary Price]

Â 

The top of BuzzFeed News. Youâ€™ve likely heard: BuzzFeed Inc. has shut down BuzzFeed News, where I worked from 2014 to early 2022. In July 2018, the newsroom launched its own website, BuzzFeedNews.com, distinct from BuzzFeed.com. The top of the new homepage featured a â€œTrendingâ€ strip, with links to a handful of editor-selected articles. A few months later, I wrote a computer script to save the text, URL, and position of each link on the strip. My personal server ran that script every five minutes (with occasional interruptions) until the newsroomâ€™s final day of operation on May 5. Hereâ€™s what it saw. Read more: â€œThe Ultimate Oral History Of BuzzFeed News,â€ as told by many of my wonderful former colleagues.

Â 

Forty years of financial reforms. A decade-plus ago, a team of IMF economists published â€œA New Database of Financial Reforms,â€ recording changes to financial policy in 91 economies from 1973 to 2005. They did so â€œalong seven different dimensions: credit controls and reserve requirements, interest rate controls, entry barriers, state ownership, policies on securities markets, banking regulations, and restrictions on the capital account.â€ Last year, Sawa Omori, a political scientist who assisted with that project, introduced a revised and updated version, expanding the coverage to 100 economies, extending it through 2013, and refining the seven original dimensions into 20 subdimensions.

Â 

Parking reforms. The Parking Reform Network, a US-based nonprofit that aims â€œto discourage the building of too much parking supply,â€ has compiled a map and dataset of ~1,400 relevant local mandates. They focus on policies that reduce or eliminate minimum parking requirements for new developments, or set maximums. For each mandate, the dataset provides a summary and indicates its location, status, category, geographic scope, affected land use, and more. Related: Parking lots in the central areas of 50+ cities, as mapped by the organization. [h/t Derek M. Jones]

Â 

Protected European ham. In the world of food and wine, geographical indications protect traditional local producers against imitators â€” Champagne being a famous example. To explore the relationship between protected region size and product price, Gero Laurenz HÃ¶hn et al. have collected the prices of protected and non-protected European ham from dozens of supermarket websites. The 22 protected varieties in the dataset (such as Italyâ€™s Prosciutto di Parma and Spainâ€™s JamÃ³n de TrevÃ©lez) come from nine countries. Related: eAmbrosia, the EUâ€™s downloadable register of protected indications.

Â 

Dataset suggestions? Criticism? Praise? Send hammy feedback to jsvine@gmail.com, or just reply to this email. // Looking for past datasets? This spreadsheet contains them all. // Visit data-is-plural.com to subscribe and to browse past editions. // Listen to the podcast to hear humans. // Swing by the Instagram and/or Mastodon account for multimedia and bonus links.
entry.summary: Aviation accident investigations, the top of BuzzFeed News, forty years of financial reforms, parking reforms, and protected European ham.

entry.title: Data Is Plural â€” 2023.05.17 edition
entry.content:
Controlled substances lost and stolen, international case law, ICE database misconduct, real effective exchange rates, and collective nouns.

Â 

Controlled substances lost and stolen. In response to a Data Liberation Project Freedom of Information Act request, the US Drug Enforcement Administration last week sent me data counting the thefts and other losses of controlled substances and â€œlisted chemicalsâ€ that regulated entities have reported to the agency. The DEA provided the records as two spreadsheet files, which Iâ€™ve also converted into tidy CSVs. They indicate the number of incidents by state, type of business (pharmacy, importer, distributor, etc.), and type of loss (burglary, hijacking, natural disaster, etc.), plus the total quantities stolen/lost. Read more: Yesterdayâ€™s Data Liberation Project newsletter, featuring some numbers that caught my eye.

Â 

International case law. â€œThe quantitative analysis of international legal data is still in its infancy, a situation which is exacerbated by the lack of high-quality open access data sets,â€ writes SeÃ¡n Fobbe in a 2022 paper in Journal of Empirical Legal Studies. To this end, Fobbeâ€™s â€œpresent[s] the first two of a new seriesâ€ of such resources, â€œcovering one hundred years of case law of the primary judicial organs of the United Nations and the League of Nations.â€ The datasets â€”Â for the Permanent Court of International Justice (covering 1922â€“1940) and for the International Court of Justice (1947â€“present) â€”Â include case metadata, linguistic metrics, and the full text (in English and French) of the courtsâ€™ opinions, orders, and other key documents.

Â 

ICE database misconduct. â€œSince 2016, hundreds of US Immigration and Customs Enforcement employees and contractors have faced internal investigations into abuse of confidential law enforcement databases and agency computers,â€ Dhruv Mehrotra reports in Wired, based on disciplinary database records Mehrotra obtained via a Freedom of Information Act request. ICE provided 414 rows of records. Each represents an alleged misconduct incident and provides a summary, date of occurrence, date reported, location, several categorizations, case resolution, and more. Wired has also added a column identifying the database in question, based on the summary. [h/t Andrew Couts + Sebastian Lammers]

Â 

Weighted, inflation-adjusted exchange rates. A countryâ€™s real effective exchange rate is its average exchange rate with its trading partners, weighted by trade volume and adjusted for inflation. Economist Zsolt Darvas maintains a dataset that estimates these rates for 178 countries and the eurozone, by month and year. The project, which updates a dataset and methodology Darvas first published in 2012, uses data from international organizations, national statistics offices, and central banks.

Â 

Collective nouns. Daniel E. Meyers has consulted dozens of sources to compile The Collective Noun Catalog, which presents an inundation of 7,300+ such constructs, such as a pulse of cardiologists and a warren of wombats. The projectâ€™s spreadsheet lists each collective nounâ€™s subject, category, notes, and primary sources â€” some of which date to the 1400s.

Â 

Dataset suggestions? Criticism? Praise? Send a pulse of feedback to jsvine@gmail.com, or just reply to this email. // Looking for past datasets? This spreadsheet contains them all. // Visit data-is-plural.com to subscribe and to browse past editions. // Listen to the podcast to hear humans. // Swing by the Instagram and/or Mastodon account for multimedia and bonus links.
entry.summary: Controlled substances lost and stolen, international case law, ICE database misconduct, real effective exchange rates, and collective nouns.

entry.title: Data Is Plural â€” 2023.05.10 edition
entry.content:
Prison demographics, more AI incidents, blocked rail crossings, grammatical phenomena, and planetary nomenclature.

Â 

ğŸ“ Reader Evelyn Martin has published explorations of data on electricity demand (DIP 2022.10.05), giant pumpkins (DIP 2022.10.26), and ICE solitary confinement (DIP 2019.06.12) discovered through Data Is Plural. (Have you published something with data you found via DIP? Click here to let me know.)

Â 

Prison demographics. In a recent paper in Nature, Brennan Klein et al. describe how they â€œmanually assembled and validated a dataset covering all 50 US states, the District of Columbia and the Federal Bureau of Prisons to both quantify the widening racial disparity observed during the first year of the COVID-19 pandemic and uncover its plausible causes.â€ Their Dataset on Incarcerated Populations provides the monthly number (or interpolated estimates) of people, by race/ethnicity, in each prison system. The dataset goes back at least to 2010 for most states; for 18 states, it also includes admission/release counts. Related: The Bureau of Justice Statisticsâ€™ annual data on prison demographics, which provide state-level counts by sex but not race/ethnicity. Previously: The Vera Instituteâ€™s Incarceration Trends Dataset (DIP 2019.01.02) and NYU Public Safety Labâ€™s Jail Data Initiative (DIP 2023.04.12). [h/t Shawn Musgrave]

Â 

More AI incidents. The AI, Algorithmic, and Automation Incidents and Controversies initiative, founded by Charlie Pownall in 2019, maintains a repository of such events, as well as related systems (e.g., GPT-4) and datasets (e.g., Labeled Faces in the Wild). The projectâ€™s spreadsheet features 1,000+ entries, each listing a title, type, year, country, sector, operator, purpose, and more â€”Â and linking to more detailed descriptions on AIAAICâ€™s website. Previously: The AI Incident Database (DIP 2023.04.19).

Â 

Blocked rail crossings. â€œAs rail profits soar, blocked crossings force kids to crawl under trains to get to school,â€ a recent investigation by ProPublica and InvestigateTV has found. In addition to on-the-ground reporting, photos, and video, the article cites the Federal Railroad Administrationâ€™s database of blocked crossing complaints. The databaseâ€™s ~70,000 reports, going back to December 2019, each list a crossing ID, street, city, state, railroad, reported incident date, duration, reason, impacts, and additional comments. Related: The FRAâ€™s database of all rail crossings. [h/t Tom Hughes]

Â 

Grammatical phenomena. Grambank, the result of a collaboration involving 100+ linguists, examines a range of grammatical phenomena, â€œfrom word order to verbal tense, nominal plurals, and many other well-studied comparative linguistic variables.â€ The projectâ€™s dataset, available to download and explore online, spans 195 such features across 2,400+ languages and dialects. For instance, hereâ€™s the page for feature GB030, which asks, â€œIs there a gender distinction in independent 3rd person pronouns?â€ [h/t Robin Sloan]

Â 

Planetary nomenclature. The International Astronomical Unionâ€™s Gazetteer of Planetary Nomenclature â€œprovides a unique system of official names for planetary surface features, natural satellites, dwarf planets, and planetary rings for the benefit of the international science community, educators, and the general public.â€ You can browse, search, and the download the data, as well as view images of their locations. As seen in: Cinzia Bonginoâ€™s The Names on the Moon. [h/t Giuseppe Sollazzo]

Â 

Dataset suggestions? Criticism? Praise? Send interplanetary feedback to jsvine@gmail.com, or just reply to this email. // Looking for past datasets? This spreadsheet contains them all. // Visit data-is-plural.com to subscribe and to browse past editions. // Listen to the podcast to hear humans. // Swing by the Instagram and/or Mastodon account for multimedia and bonus links.
entry.summary: Prison demographics, more AI incidents, blocked rail crossings, grammatical phenomena, and planetary nomenclature.
